data.text: Bont toe box is a bit wide compared to most brands. The entire sole is basically a bathtub that your foot goes in. It completely encompasses your foot about 1/2‚Äù deep. The Riot isn‚Äôt carbon fiber per say, but rather a composite of carbon and other materials, Vapor and other higher end models are true carbon fiber. The toe box is quite spacious if you get the correct size and the entire shoe is heat moldable. I‚Äôm honestly not sure where the ‚Äúcarbon across the front of the toe box‚Äù comes from. My toes don‚Äôt even touch the front of the toe box and the only thing above my toes is leather. If I had to come up with one complaint, If you do any technical riding that you would normally roll your foot a bit and get the bike side to side, it does feel a little less connected. In that you don‚Äôt feel what the bike is doing under your feet as much. This is why I still prefer the RX8 on the mountain bike. Neither one of them are good for walking though.

data.text: Specialized S-Works Recons are super-stiff and very comfortable on the bike (except for one issue). Many people (myself included) experience some uncomfortable rubbing from the un padded edge of the shoe‚Äôs tongue. Walking is not comfortable, and the rubber pontoons on the carbon sole wear shockingly fast, so not the best choice for rides/races where you have to get off the bike. I improved the traction of the shoes a bit by installing rubber studs for soccer shoes in the toe stud holes. I love the dual Boas for dialing in the fit on the fly, but I do find that the Boas tend to loosen during rides. I haven‚Äôt had lace-up cycling shoes in many years, but they annoyed me back in the day. And, yes, these are very expensive shoes.
